div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to George [H. Ramsey], December [3], 1928
div1.opener:
Book, Bibliography
Ramsey, George H.
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
December 3, 1928.
Dear George:
div1.p:
“S. O. S!” (as per enclosure). The book, “at long last,” is
really nearing completion--i. e. turned over the MS for final editing
to Frost in September. Miss Brown, my associate, and I, however, have
still been “working our heads off” trying to clear up unverified ref-
erences, and if you can help us out with even one of those on the en-
closed list we will bless you forever!

L. O. Howard took the top part of this list to try to locate the
refs. and I sent the bottem to J. W. W. Stevens, from whom I have heard
nothing, however. I am afraid he did not get it.

It was so good to hear from you just before you left West Africa,
and it will be better still to see you! If you have a chance, do drop
me a line as to when you expect to reach New York. I am planning to go
up there soon to stay with a very dear friend of mine, Mrs. Paul Morton
Stewart, née Countess Pelligrini of Genoa. You'd like her a lot, also
“P. M.” her husband.

Owing to flu last fall and the heat of the past summer the work
on the book has been a perfect nightmare physically. It has, however,
been most interesting, despite this, and its a tremendous relief to
feel that it is nearly done. Frost has had the flu for the past few
weeks. I had tea at the Howells not long ago and Howell said that
he was really uneasy at Doull's account of Jack. However, Mrs. Frost
reports by long distance that he is better. I've too many things to
tell you consider doing so in office hours--and, until this job is
done, all hours are office hours. Au revoir then and--I can't tell you
how good it will be to see you again
